text.content: One of the most effective treatments for PTSD is talk therapy.  Find a counselor your loved one feels comfortable with.

While many kinds of talk therapy can be helpful, the best possible treatment is a trauma-specific therapy.  These are: Prolonged Exposure, Cognitive Processing Therapy, and Eye Movement Desensitization and Retraining (or EMDR).
Exercise can be an important part of improving mood. If youâ€™re physically able, you might benefit from a few minutes of exercise each day.
Mindfulness, or mindful meditation practice, has been shown to be very effective at reducing distress and PTSD symptoms. Try the Mindfulness Tools in this app!
Talk with a professional coach, for free, about how to get the care you need. Call Coaching into Care:
There are some medications that have been shown to help with PTSD, including Celexa, Paxil, Prozac, and Zoloft. Talk with your doctor.
PTSD can affect everyone in the family. Family therapy is a helpful way to bring family members together and to better understand one another in a safe, caring space.

Feeling sad, down, heavy or blue most of the time for more than 2 weeks can be a sign of depression. If you are concerned that you may be depressed, talk with your health care provider or reach out to a counselor for support. You can also call the Veterans Crisis Line at
